https://prez.dev/description.@value: The study of the physics of the Earth, especially its electrical, gravitational and magnetic fields and propagation of elastic (seismic) waves within it. Source: Schlumberger Oilfield Glossary
The subject is an instance of a class.
The defininition of the subject resource.
An idea or notion; a unit of thought
Relates a concept to a concept that is more general in meaning
A statement or formal explanation of the meaning of a concept

skos:exactMatch is used to link two concepts, indicating a high degree of confidence that the concepts can be used interchangeably across a wide range of information retrieval applications. skos:exactMatch is a transitive property, and is a sub-property of skos:closeMatch
A note about the past state/use/meaning of a concept
Relates a resource (for example a concept) to a concept scheme in which it is included
Relates a concept to a concept that is more specific in meaning
A notation, also known as classification code, is a string of characters such as 'T58.5' or '303.4833' used to uniquely identify a concept within the scope of a given concept scheme
The preferred lexical label for a resource, in a given language

https://prez.dev/label.@value: 1297.0 ANZSRC - Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification, 2020: Fields of Research (FoR)

https://prez.dev/description.@value: This group covers geophysics.

A categorization of disciplines or topics that the broad field of Earth science can be subdivided into, i.e. a listing of the Fields of Research, or subjects, to which a geoscience dataset, publication, observation/activity, or entity pertains. The vocabulary also contains relevant disciplines that intersect with the various Earth science fields, such as biological sciences and built environment and design, as well as entries related to collection and heritage management. Notations included are those from the 2020 ANZSRC listing (see History Note) or in common use in the geoscience community.

A discipline concerned with investigating the Earth from the surface to a depth of several kilometres, specifically aiming to meet the growing demands for natural resources and geo-energies, to respond to the effects of climate change, to provide critical data for civil engineers, and to forecast the effects of natural hazards.

https://prez.dev/label.@value: electrical and electromagnetic methods in geophysics

https://prez.dev/description.@value: Geophysical methods that involve the use of electrical and electromagnetic fields to study the subsurface properties of the Earth. These methods exploit the interaction between electromagnetic waves and the electrical conductivity, permittivity, and magnetic susceptibility of subsurface materials.

The science of measuring and representing the geometry (size and shape) of the Earth and the precise location of points on its surface; it includes the determination of the gravitational field of the Earth and the study of temporal variations such as Earth tides, polar motion, and rotation of the Earth.

A subfield of geophysics dealing with the forces and processes of the interior of the Earth. It applies physics, chemistry and mathematics to the understanding of how mantle convection leads to plate tectonics and geological phenomena such as seafloor spreading, mountain building, volcanoes, earthquakes, faulting and so on. It also attempts to probe the internal activities of the Earth by measuring magnetic fields, gravity, and seismic waves, as well as the mineralogy of rocks and their isotopic composition.
The study of fluid dynamics of naturally occurring flows, such as lava flows, oceans, and planetary atmospheres, on Earth and other planets.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#defi.@value: A natural science concerned with the physical processes and physical properties of the Earth and its surrounding space environment, and the use of quantitative methods for their analysis. It includes several disciplines focusing on the study of the Earth's electrical, gravitational and magnetic fields and the propagation of elastic (seismic) waves within it.

http://www.w3.org/2004/02/skos/core#hist.@value: From the Fields of Research vocabulary from the Australian and New Zealand Standard Research Classification (ANZSRC, 2020). Definition adapted from Glossary of geology (5th edition revised; Neuendorf et al., 2011) and Wikipedia.

https://prez.dev/description.@value: A natural science concerned with the physical processes and physical properties of the Earth and its surrounding space environment, and the use of quantitative methods for their analysis. It includes several disciplines focusing on the study of the Earth's electrical, gravitational and magnetic fields and the propagation of elastic (seismic) waves within it.
Geophysical data and information not otherwise described by other sub-categories of geophysics.
The study of heatflow and radioactive activity within the Earth.
The measure of changes in gravity due to variations in the density of the rocks to remotely map the distribution of different rock types and the structure of rocks in the Earth's subsurface.

The study of physical phenomena associated with moving electricity in conductive rocks or the permanent magnetic effects of naturally magnetic rocks, and the study of natural remanent magnetization of Earth materials in order to determine the direction, and indirectly intensity, of the Earth's magnetic field in the geological past.

The study of the physical and mechanical properties of rocks. Petrophysics focuses on how the microstructure of porous geological materials affects their mechanical, electrical, thermal, fluid flow, and sonic properties. Rock mechanics considers the mechanical or geomechanical properties of rocks, including reservoir strength, elastic properties, hardness, ultrasonic behaviour, index characteristics, and in situ stresses.

The scientific study of earthquakes and the propagation of elastic waves both natural and artificially generated through the Earth or through other planetary bodies. The field also includes studies of earthquake environmental effects such as tsunamis as well as diverse seismic sources such as volcanic, tectonic, oceanic, atmospheric, and artificial processes such as explosions. Seismic exploration is a method of exploration geophysics that uses the principles of seismology to estimate the properties of the Earth's subsurface from artificially generated seismic waves.

The non-destructive, three-dimensional characterization of earth and planetary materials that uses material-penetrating energy sources. Tomography methods in Earth Science include experiments in controlled laboratory settings such as computed tomography of rock samples or soils, and field experiments such as seismic tomography of the Solid Earth.
A profile for SKOS Concept Schemes
A citation or reference to another creative work, such as another publication, web page, scholarly article, etc
